user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtTest_AddSubTest:
```c
void UtTest_AddSubTest(void (*Test)(void), void (*Setup)(void), void (*Teardown)(void), const char *GroupName,
                       const char *TestName)
{
    char        CompleteTestName[128];
    const char *GroupPtr;
    const char *TestPtr;

    /* Remove any common prefix between the two names.
     * They are often function names that all start with "Test_XXX"
     * and this repetitive information just becomes clutter.
     */
    GroupPtr = GroupName;
    TestPtr  = TestName;
    while (*GroupPtr != 0 && *GroupPtr == *TestPtr)
    {
        ++GroupPtr;
        ++TestPtr;
    }

    /*
     * Only break at an underscore(_) to avoid weird effects
     */
    while (TestPtr > TestName && *TestPtr != '_')
    {
        --TestPtr;
    }
    if (*TestPtr == '_')
    {
        ++TestPtr;
    }

    /*
     * Remove a remaining "Test_" prefix on the group name.
     * Again just to remove common repetitive content
     */
    GroupPtr = GroupName;
    if (strncmp(GroupPtr, "Test_", 5) == 0)
    {
        GroupPtr += 5;
    }

    (void)snprintf(CompleteTestName, sizeof(CompleteTestName), "%s.%s", GroupPtr, TestPtr);

    UtTest_AddCommon(Test, Setup, Teardown, CompleteTestName, UTASSERT_GROUP_TEST);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtTest_AddSubTest:
void UtTest_AddCommon(void (*Test)(void), void (*Setup)(void), void (*Teardown)(void), const char *TestName,
                      uint32 EntryType)
{
    UtTestDataBaseEntry_t UtTestDataBaseEntry;

    memset(&UtTestDataBaseEntry, 0, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry));
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Test     = Test;
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Setup    = Setup;
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Teardown = Teardown;
    if (TestName != NULL)
    {
        strncpy(UtTestDataBaseEntry.TestName, TestName, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry.TestName) - 1);
    }

    UT_BSP_Lock();
    UtList_Add(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr, &UtTestDataBaseEntry, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry_t), EntryType);
    UT_BSP_Unlock();
}
...
void UtList_Add(UtListHead_t *ListHead, void *Data, uint32 DataSize, uint32 Tag)
{
    UtListNode_t *TagHead;
    UtListNode_t *NewNode;

    TagHead = UtList_GetHead(ListHead, Tag);
    if (TagHead != NULL)
    {
        NewNode      = UtList_NewNode(Data, DataSize);
        NewNode->Tag = Tag;
        UtList_Insert_Before(TagHead, NewNode);
    }
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: void UtList_Add(UtListHead_t *ListHead, void *Data, uint32 DataSize, uint32 Tag)
explanation: Other pointer occurrences in the provided code do not need investigation for Rule 8.13: GroupName and TestName parameters are already const-qualified (const char *). Local string pointers GroupPtr and TestPtr are declared as const char *. The CompleteTestName object is a mutable character array (needed to build the name). The UtTest_AddCommon Test/Setup/Teardown parameters are function pointers (const-qualification of the pointed-to function type is not applicable in this context). The UtList head pointer is used to modify the list and therefore should remain non-const. Thus only the above fragments (where non-const void* data is accepted/passed) are potential violations to be investigated.
